channel.title: Economy
channel.description:
Tell me what you think of this idea:
For the economy, I wouldn't include any starter in the beginning, only basic items in the shops, meaning the essentials such as: Armor and weapons up to Mithril/Willow/Basic Robes (Forgot name), and the standard general store items. In order to get higher items, the player must A) Try to get it as a drop, with the rates being rather high, or B) Make it using their skills. So essentially, the players would be feeding the servers economy. Now, lets say at one point many players were getting many rare items due to luck with drops, and then those players all quit, giving away their items, and eventually having a lower player count, and a high amount of cash flowing through the economy, I would have a counter-measure. This counter-measure would be to lower the global price of that item of course, then make that item seem less desirable somehow, by introducing a new item, maybe a custom, or an unorthodox item, and making it seem desirable. Do you think the players would go with it? Maybe I would have to give the item some bonuses while skilling or something..

item.title: Economy
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

runescape free market 2012. jk

in all seriousness… i’m sure by adopting the ultima model of gameplay somewhat in an rs server (woot experimentation) you could actually make contracts a metagame idea and players enforce them in a full pvp world!! if i make a forum request to you to get me shitloads of shit and i pay up front, if you don’t deliver on my contract i can then basically enforce my will and hire people to kill you and rob your bank (<-- new game mechanic anyone? 99 thieving may just get useful…) until i get what i want back. or i could just get them to kill you repeatedly as punishment. or i could write up a player-imprisonment mechanic where players can imprison others, that would be cool although very susceptible to high-level pkers going insane and imprisoning everyone… make it costly i guess

Read full topic

item.title: Economy
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

tyb97:

I see. Almost like quests but player-issued?

Basically yes. This might require some client-side interface changes to be made (new sidebar interface for contracts available to the player, contracts in progress, completed contracts, etc) for it to be a concise functionality.

There’s loads of different ways that you can augment an economy, but the most effective one would be something similar to the Grand Exchange, where people are able to set their own prices. Giving people options is what makes/breaks an economy.

And as said earlier, an items “true value” is also taken into consideration. You don’t have to have party hats, or santa hats as rare items. You could sell them in the general store as gifts for 10 GP if you wanted. The reason they’re rare in RuneScape, is because they were only given out one year, at the very beginning, and a large span of time has passed since then, making the net amount available very little. If you had trimmed armor as a 1% chance in a treasure trail/difficult boss, then it would be more rare than party hats, and thus more valuable. The same applies to gilded armor, or anything you want.

Read full topic

item.title: Economy
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

I see. Almost like quests but player-issued?

Read full topic

item.title: Economy
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

tyb97:

Contract system? Explain.

I got the idea from EVE Online. It wont replace an economy (nor should it), but it provides a buffer between the price of an item, and the amount of effort needed to get it. I’ll try to explain it the best I can.

A player can issue a contract, which entails either buying or selling a certain amount of given items. So I could create a contract, in which a person, or a group of people, mine for me 10k rune ess. Each contract would have an expiration time, by which the contract must be completed. If someone has accepted the contract, and the expiration time is near, they could either request an extension from the issuer, or pay the collateral for not completing the contract in time. After a contract has been successfully completed, the person who accepted the contract would receive the reward.

Contract:
Issuer: zyle1992
Expiration: 11/23/2012 17:00
Requirements:
    Rune Ess: 10,000
    Air Runes: 1,000

Collateral:
    Coins: 50,000

Reward:
    Coins: 1,250,000

After a player sees the contract, they can either accept it then, and get to work, or accept and complete the contract if they already have the required items, or contact the issuer, and negotiate a different deal.

This would work best in addition to an Exchange type system, as it provides the players with more control

EDIT: I should also note that it would be wise to “reserve” the detailed items. Let’s say a person drafts a contract, with a 22m coin reward. If they don’t have the 22m as a reward, they should not be able to create the contract. Likewise, if they have 22m, create the contract, they shouldn’t be permitted to have less than that amount at any time (killed, trade it, buy other items, or anything else that brings them below 22m). Or you can just have the items removed at the time of creation so exploiting it doesn’t become possible.

Another idea is to have contracts, or mini-quests given by random Npcs. Let’s say there’s some guy in Lumbridge, the player talks to him, finds out that some goblins in the abandoned house took something from him, and he’ll pay coins/items to get it back. Or the guards of the local city can hire you to kill goblins/black wizards/* and will pay you for it.

Read full topic

item.title: Economy
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Contract system? Explain.

Read full topic

item.title: Economy
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

If you have to program in an economy, you’re doing it wrong. An economy is something that should be… manifested by the players, and their actions. The most you should have to do is change the drop tables if things get a little out of hand (for example, KQ dropping a dragon med helm after every fight or something), or if there’s a dupe, and players get loads of high valued items.

Or you can implement a contract system (which I’m working on now). It might be able to provide a buffer to manipulation.

Read full topic

item.title: Economy
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Kidpaparoach, post:24, topic:464060”][quote author=Tutorial link=topic=567841.msg4126413#msg4126413 date=1350487161]
I believe a single valued item should be worth no more than the max cash stack for starters. From there you should focus on item drop rates and availability rather than cash becoming inflated.
[/quote]
Ideally no more than 300m tbh, 500m tops. Like the old Rs eco. The old Rs eco was good, just inflate the money making but think of a fair way to remove gp from the eco.[/quote]why put a price on items? you could just control the supply of rares and let the true value of them reflect itself in the economy naturally. hypothetically, conditions could be made that would result in a rare item only being worth 100k or so, but 100k could be as difficult to obtain on that server as 500m is on another. it all boils down to ‘true value’ in the end

Read full topic

item.title: Economy
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“I am beast, post:15, topic:464060”][quote author=s1gma link=topic=567841.msg4124735#msg4124735 date=1350244321]

The only sure fire way to control an economy is to have some form of a grand exchange and have it write to a chart. That way what there’s more of in the game you can up the price and when there’s less you can lower the price.
[/quote]that’s the most boring proposition for an economy i have ever heard. why not implement a way for you to control the supply of resources instead, so you have a modifiable multiplier for things like rare drop rates, ore respawn times, tree respawn times, monster respawn times blahblah. rather than your boring control everything!!! crap you can fiddle with the multipliers and notice what happens to your server economy. when you lower the spawn time for certain boss monsters and the rare drop rate, you’ll see a sure fire increase in the price of a drop (especially if it’s really fucking useful). natural resources e.g. food, ore and wood would be fun to manipulate too (it’s a shame that weapons don’t decay over time though).

You can make them decay… That would also stimulate the need for these items as they decay.[/quote]yeah, it’ll require a bit of work but it’s definitely possible to do it.

[quote=“tyb97, post:16, topic:464060”][quote author=I am beast link=topic=567841.msg4125306#msg4125306 date=1350331512]

The only sure fire way to control an economy is to have some form of a grand exchange and have it write to a chart. That way what there’s more of in the game you can up the price and when there’s less you can lower the price.
[/quote]that’s the most boring proposition for an economy i have ever heard. why not implement a way for you to control the supply of resources instead, so you have a modifiable multiplier for things like rare drop rates, ore respawn times, tree respawn times, monster respawn times blahblah. rather than your boring control everything!!! crap you can fiddle with the multipliers and notice what happens to your server economy. when you lower the spawn time for certain boss monsters and the rare drop rate, you’ll see a sure fire increase in the price of a drop (especially if it’s really fucking useful). natural resources e.g. food, ore and wood would be fun to manipulate too (it’s a shame that weapons don’t decay over time though).

You can make them decay… That would also stimulate the need for these items as they decay.

Decaying… That’s an interesting way to keep the economy flowing, maybe if an item gets too abundant, make some sort of server event in where these items degrade or are “stolen”, where the player can get it back, and if he fails he loses it.[/quote]or avoid such random occurrences and just increase the decay rate multiplier if you really need to.

Read full topic

item.title: Economy
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

For a successful economy you need it to be ever changing, a way for items to be removed from the game fairly and so forth.
I wont go into details but you’ll understand how to make a successful economy over time hopefully.

Read full topic

item.title: Economy
item.dc:creator: @Onix Onix
item.description:
@Onix wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:17, topic:464060”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=567841.msg4125308#msg4125308 date=1350331638]

The only sure fire way to control an economy is to have some form of a grand exchange and have it write to a chart. That way what there’s more of in the game you can up the price and when there’s less you can lower the price.
[/quote]that’s the most boring proposition for an economy i have ever heard. why not implement a way for you to control the supply of resources instead, so you have a modifiable multiplier for things like rare drop rates, ore respawn times, tree respawn times, monster respawn times blahblah. rather than your boring control everything!!! crap you can fiddle with the multipliers and notice what happens to your server economy. when you lower the spawn time for certain boss monsters and the rare drop rate, you’ll see a sure fire increase in the price of a drop (especially if it’s really fucking useful). natural resources e.g. food, ore and wood would be fun to manipulate too (it’s a shame that weapons don’t decay over time though).

You can make them decay… That would also stimulate the need for these items as they decay.

Decaying… That’s an interesting way to keep the economy flowing, maybe if an item gets too abundant, make some sort of server event in where these items degrade or are “stolen”, where the player can get it back, and if he fails he loses it.

Hence the reason why MMORPGS have item durability.[/quote]Which introduces ‘cash shop’ games where you spend money to keep your virtual items from breaking. That is how many free MMO companies get rich.

Read full topic
